results.title: Tour of duty
results.creator_credit: Paul Rayment, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While he saw it as his duty to defend his country against communism, it wasn’t until Paul Rayment went to Vietnam that he realised how lucky Australia really was. However, on his return, Rayment became estranged from his community and friends, and it took a while to rebuild those ties and his connection to the country he had earlier set out to defend.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Rayment, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: A Look from their side
results.creator_credit: Robert Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Reflecting on his service in Borneo during World War II, Robert Cole was impressed by the kindness and warmth of the local people, despite being forced to live through war and poverty. In doing so, they taught Cole about gratitude.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Boy who came in from the cold
results.creator_credit: Jack Darling, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alfred (Jack) Darling was a gunner on the ANZAC during the Korean War. The boys came up with as many ways as possible to overcome the Korean winter, including growing a beard, which required permission from the captain.

results.title: Sink or swim
results.creator_credit: Gwynneth Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Gwynneth Cole joined the army in 1944, roles for women were limited. While Cole didn’t get to serve on the front line, she was posted to different bases in Australia as a nurse and faced many hardships and the realities of war. Cole greatly values her time in the army and reflects on the opportunities for women and the independent streak she has passed on to her four daughters.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gwynneth Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Singapore dollars
results.creator_credit: Edward Dunstan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Edward Dunstan served in the Australian Navy for 20 years, spending a significant part of that time in Singapore. While he enjoyed his time there, Dunstan also has some bad memories, not least of all was how he was received by his fellow Australians on his return. However, these experiences have encouraged him to help others through his work at the RSL.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edward Dunstan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Folk, Rhythm and Life
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Skermer Famliy have been running the Bilyana ‘Folk Rhythm & Life Festival’, in north-eastern Victoria, since 1996 and in the process raising funds for local and international charities. The festival has always been environmentally sustainable, with the original “drop dunnies” developed by Hamish Skermer now being used not only in Eldorado but also at festivals in Australia and overseas.

results.title: The Eldorado Museum
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Sue Phillips, Sandra Buchan and Geoff Milne take us on a tour of the Eldorado Museum and share the rich history of the pioneering families who established infrastructure and made the northern Victorian town of Eldorado what it is in 2012.

results.title: Artists of Eldorado
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet local artists Maureen Hearn, Denise Ellison, Thea Day, Sandra Buchan and Sam Anderson, and learn about their inspirations and artistic practice. Moved by the magic of Eldorado, in northern Victoria, these artists are never short of inspiration. Day, Ellison and Buchan make time each week to get together and share their passion for painting and line drawing. Hearn works out of her studio that showcases her love of the river and obsession with chickens. Anderson is a metal sculptor who works on his family farm creating large scale works, such as his ‘Gorilla’, which must be seen to be believed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

results.title: The Greta Swamp
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: The area surrounding Greta, in north-eastern Victoria, used to be a swamp, home to indigenous wildlife and the mythical Bunyip creature. The swamp was drained as part of a government employment project in the 1890s, leaving behind rich fertile land ideal for grazing, however it also created a complete change in the area around Greta, especially in the hill country, causing environmental damage. One hundred years on and local Land Care members Anthony and David Griffiths, along with 2012 Land Care President Phil Gottschling, have dedicated their time and energy to try and reverse the effects of the dredging and are revegetating their land to restore balance to the environment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

The swamp was drained as part of a government employment project in the 1890s, leaving behind rich fertile land ideal for grazing, however it also created a complete change in the area around Greta, especially in the hill country, causing environmental damage. One hundred years on and local Land Care members Anthony and David Griffiths, along with 2012 Land Care President Phil Gottschling, have dedicated their time and energy to try and reverse the effects of the dredging and are revegetating their land to restore balance to the environment.
description_for_label: The area surrounding Greta, in north-eastern Victoria, used to be a swamp, home to indigenous wildlife and the mythical Bunyip creature. The swamp was drained as part of a government employment project in the 1890s, leaving behind rich fertile land ideal for grazing, however it also created a complete change in the area around Greta, especially in the hill country, causing environmental damage. One hundred years on and local Land Care members Anthony and David Griffiths, along with 2012 Land Care President Phil Gottschling, have dedicated their time and energy to try and reverse the effects of the dredging and are revegetating their land to restore balance to the environment.

results.title: Greta Craft Group
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Women come from great distances bringing their knitting needles, sewing machines and a good yarn to the weekly Greta Craft Group. The group was started by Kath White in the early 1990s when, as a young mum and new to the area, she reached out to other mums for some companionship. The group grew from there and became so popular they needed a waiting list for those interested to join - as Winifred Suffield suggests “craft is just an excuse to meet”. 2012 President Helen Bird and long time members Nola Jones and Julie White, speak about the support and friendship that the group has provided over decades. We hear the sounds of laughter and chatter as the ladies make all sorts of beautiful crafts which they provide to charities, both locally and internationally.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

The group was started by Kath White in the early 1990s when, as a young mum and new to the area, she reached out to other mums for some companionship.
